items.content:
Tule.Slo:

Kerndoel 39 Oriëntatie op jezelf en op de wereld, mens en samenleving

De leerlingen leren met zorg om te gaan met het milieu

Kerndoel 42 Oriëntatie op jezelf en op de wereld, natuur en techniek

De leerlingen leren onderzoek doen naar materialen en natuurkundige verschijnselen, zoals licht, geluid, elektriciteit, kracht, magnetisme en temperatuur

Kerndoel 44 Oriëntatie op jezelf en op de wereld, natuur en techniek

De leerlingen leren bij producten uit hun eigen omgeving relaties te leggen tussen de werking, de vorm en het materiaalgebruik

Kerndoel 45 Oriëntatie op jezelf en op de wereld, natuur en techniek

De leerlingen leren oplossingen voor technische problemen te ontwerpen, deze uit te voeren en te evalueren

IPC:

Natuur en Techniek 3.2

De leerlingen zijn instaat om wetenschappelijke onderzoeken uit te voeren

Natuur en Techniek 3.9

De leerlingen zijn in staat om met enige mate van precisie te werken met allerhande gereedschappen en materialen.

De leerlingen zijn praktisch bezig aan de hand van verschillende wetenschappelijke experimenten om de begrippen 'conduction', 'insulation', 'convection', 'radiation' en 'electrical circuit' te onderzoeken.

Activiteit 1 = De leerlingen maken een ijshand.

Activiteit 2 = Science test

Experiment 1: Hoe houden we iets koud?

Experiment 2: Hoe blijft iets warm?

Vervolgopdracht horende bij experiment 1 en/of 2: Straling, Geleiding, Convectie

Activiteit 3 = Circuits en geleiders

Activiteit 4 = Leerlingen maken een electriciteitsspel

Activiteit 5 = Extra materialen en activiteiten (online)

A clearly layed-out powerpoint taking the children through some simple steps of setting up a science investigation.

Recording sheet

Game: Running dictation
Challenge: To be the quickest and the most accurate

Description:

Children can revise what materials conduct or insulate electricity or heat. The teacher can explain every word and picture or the children can guess the words to the pictures. Before the lesson the children should know what sort of material is conducting or insulating electricity or heat.

Vocabulary:

Frying-pan, Hot-water bottle, Chair, Garden gloves, Water bottle, Thermos flask, Rubber floormat, Porcelain watering-can, Plastic garden chair, Lemon, Gold chain, Pencil, Iron watering-can, Plastic clogs, Iron garden chair, Plastic watering-can, Water, Coffee cup, Stewpan, Wooden clogs, conductor, insulator.

Functional language:

Dictate to your partner the word that belongs to the picture and write on the number of the picture and the corresponding word.

Place the number of the picture in the right column. Is the material a conductor or an insulator?

Instructions:

- Open the file and print on A3 the pictures and wordsheet. Print enough papers for every group. Give every couple a piece of paper.
- Pupils are divided into pairs (or threes).
- Teacher points out the papers on the wall (and if necessary indicates which text different pairs should 'run' to).
- Teacher demos with a pair by running the one of the texts, 'acting' out reading the first line and trying to remember it, running back to his partner and trying to dictate the first picture or word, deliberately forgetting the word so having to go back to re-read and then come back and finish dictating. Then he indicates that his partner needs to do the running and so on.
- Teacher checks understanding and if not, redoes the demo!
- First pair to finish raises hand and wins!
- Countdown to start
- Teacher monitors that nobody is cheating
- First pair to finish gets 100 points (write on their sheet), 2nd pair gets 98, 3rd pair 96 and so on
- Either when everyone has finished or the majority, then pairs swap their sheets with another pair.
- Display the correct answers on the screen. Pupils have to check the other pair's work against the correct version and take off 1 point for every mistake. They then write the total mark (the number of points gained according to how quickly they completed the activity minus the numbers of errors made) on the sheet and return to the other pair.
- Teacher checks who get 100, 99, 98, 97 etc. with a show of hands and awards points or stickers to the 'winning' pair(s)

Variations
To stop pupils cheating, sellotape a blank sheet of paper over the front of each text on the wall to act as a sort of flap which pupils much lift up to read what's underneath! This prevents them reading and shouting across the room!

Resources:

1

Time needed: Ongoing

Kerndoel: 42 IPC: 3.2

Description:

Fill a plastic glove with water and freeze it. Ask the class for ideas about how to make the hand melt more slowly. Try wrapping the ice hand in different materials (1). Ask the children to compare the results in a graph. Talk about how good insulators slow down the movement of heat from a warmer to a colder place and vice versa. Ask the children to present their results to the class (poster, powerpoint, photos).

Functional language:

What can we do to make it melt more slowly?, We could ….. , I think it will melt more slowly when we wrap it in …… , How will we measure this?, What do we need?

Vocabulary:

Freezing, melting, insulator, insulating, heat

Resources:

Plastic gloves

Different materials such as newspaper, kitchen towel, plastic, container, fabric, towel, jumper, cling film, tin foil, etc

Thermometers

1

Time needed: 30-60 mins

Kerndoel: 42 IPC: 3.2

Description:

Watch the video for the explanation of the term 'conduction' (3). Stop the video if necessary to explain or check the children understand the meaning of the word. Stop the video at 1:18 mins. Present the children with a written definition of the term (Conduction is the transfer of heat by touching. It moves from the warmer part to the cooler part of an object.)

Then move forward to 2:15 mins for an explanation of the term 'radiation'. (Radiation is the transfer of energy in waves. It travels through matter or empty space.)

Experiment 1: Investigating keeping cool

In groups, the children will conduct an experiment investigating insulation.

If children are not familiar with conducting a fair test, show the powerpoint mentioned above (general resources). If they are, show the powerpoint called 'insulation experiment'.

Experiment 2: staying warm

See experiment 1 but change the test question from keeping cool to staying warm.

Follow-up activity to go with experiment 1 and/or 2: Radiation, Conduction, Convection

(Can also be used independently)

song + gap fill (2, 3)

Functional language:

______ is a good choice because

Vocabulary:

Conductor, conduction, solid, glass, wool, metal, paper, plastic, cotton, stone,

good choice, bad choice, waves, energy, transfer

Resources:

1 2 3

Time needed: 45 mins

Kerndoel: 42 IPC: 3.2, 3.9

Description:

Ask the children to make a light bulb light up with only wires, a 1.5V battery and a bulb. Ask what happens when there is a break in the circuit. Point out that the wires look like they are made of plastic but that the wire inside is made of metal. Introduce the vocabulary of 'conductor' and 'insulator' and the names of the battery and light bulb.

Ask the children to find out which materials conduct electricity.

Provide each group with a selection of materials to investigate. Set up a circuit with a battery (activity 5), a bulb and a gap. First ask the children to predict when each material is put in the gap what will happen (optional: ask them to write this down) 'Paper clip: I think that the light bulb will (not) light up'.

Use the activity sheet 'Conductors of electricity' (1). Explain that poor (bad) conductors that do not let electricity through are called 'insulators'.

Functional language:

What happens when you break the circuit?

I think that ….

Paper clip: I think that the light bulb will (not) light up'

Vocabulary:

Circuit, conductor, insulator, electricity, battery, batteries, light bulb, wires, switch(es), tin foil, volt(age), bright, dim

To break the circuit, to light up, to predict

Resources:

E.g. paperclips, paper, card, fabric, rubber, wooden objects, lego cubes, keys, plastic beads, coin, glass, etc

1.5V batteries, small light bulbs

1

Time needed: 30 mins

Kerndoel: 42, 44, 45 IPC: 3.9

Description:

Ask the children to make a 'matching questions game board' for another year group (1). The matching cards can be on any topic and can be made at a later stage.

Functional language:

Make question cards and answers, put them down, attach the paperclip.

Vocabulary:

back of the board, front of the board, wire, paperclip, a bulb.

Resources:

1

Additional materials and activities

Building a circuit Heat quiz Electricity vocabulary Thermal conduction
